title: â€˜Research & Projectsâ€™
text:
My primary research foci centers around learnability and phonology. My approach in research in general is to be able to engage with the literature on big-picture questions regarding the architecture of the linguistic theory with an eye to both the computational and formal algorithmic levels of explanation; and of course to follow our strive to understand what language is from a biolinguistic perspective.




I have an inquiring mind primarily about:

phonology and child acquisition
puzzles in the data, especially with a learnability angle
artificial grammar learning


Main methods shaping my research would be:

experimental studies
computational modelling
corpus and quantitative analysis






Main topics that interest me currently are:

How do learners acquire and navigate the tension on the level of morpho-phonological patterns encompassing exceptions/inconsistencies and what do their errors and challenges reveal about modularity and the architecture of the grammar?
Which learning algorithm best capture learning trajectories as close as possible to acquisition in our computational modelling and how do competing models fare across different types of patterns on this basis?
In what ways different factors shape phonological or phonotactic acquisition, including statistical learning and soft biases irrelevant to the learning data (emerging with surfeit-of-the-stimulus phenomenon)?
In what ways do structural and channel-based biases drive language learning, language change over generations, and typological patterns?

Fascinations inside of linguistics:

How do children acquire (morpho-)syntax and phonology, and what implications does the developmental trajectory of grammatical knowledge have for the architecture of the grammar?
How is the grammar architecturally organized, and how does phonology interface with syntax and morphology within the overal structure?
What types of formal-language-theoretic approaches could allow us to understand the computational procedures involved in grammar, and how do these relate to cognitive-level explanations of language?
How have different schools of linguistic thought shaped our current understanding of language, learning, and cognitive science?

title: â€˜Research & Projectsâ€™
section: Learning Phonotactic Rules Sensitive to Sonority Sequencing Principle in Persian: Prior Bias or Experience?
text:
Learning Phonotactic Rules Sensitive to Sonority Sequencing Principle in Persian: Prior Bias or Experience?
âŒ› [2019 - 2021]
This project has focused on the SSP projection effects and learning phonotactics, using 2 acceptability judgment experiments with non-word stimuli. The goal was to test if Persian speakers exhibit any sensitivity to the SSP taking into account their linguistic experience with Persian phonotactic constraints with a CVC(C) syllable structure. Persian syllables have no attested onset clusters, and 21% of the attested coda clusters are against the SSP. The results confirmed the view that speakers can generalize their phonotactic knowledge beyond their lexicon and the fact that they exhibit some innate biases despite their lack of experience, along the lines of the POS argument.
ğŸ”— The original work is an unpublished thesis in Persian, but an English excerpt of it and the stimuli set and r scripts are accessible on an osf repository.

section: Gutturals and Pharyngealization Harmony in the Meymandi Dialect
text:
Gutturals and Pharyngealization Harmony in the Meymandi Dialect
â³ [2021 - under publication]
Co-authored chapter in the Springer Handbook of Phonetics and Phonology of Modern Iranian Languages
This study aims to investigate a phonological process involving guttarals in Meymandi, a dialect of Persian. In our analysis, we claim there is a pharyngealization harmony process in Meymandi which interacts with another common process in various dialects of Persian, Compensatory lengthening. This analyses is further accompanied by reports of acoustic measurements taken from audio recordings of speakers collected via remote fieldwork. The analysis shows phonetic evidence for this interaction.
